prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: R Dor - band 7 - angular resolution 0.04"
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Several molecular transition of SiO, SiS, H2O, AlO, AlOH, CO, TiO, TiO2, and H13CN have been selected. The transitions lie in the frequency range between 332.4-336.4 and 344.4-348.4 GHz. We aim to detect and spatially resolve SiO, SiS, H2O, and CO in SG1, and in addition AlOH, AlO, TiO, and TiO2 in SG2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
1. Requested line sensitivity and spectral resolution: The envisioned spectral lines lie in a spectral window between 332.4-336.4 GHz and 344.4-348.4 GHz, i.e. within one science goal in band 7. We have selected a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz to cover all lines; the line-free regions will be used for the analysis of the continuum (see below). Line strengths have been estimated based on the SMA survery of the supergiant VY CMa (Kaminski et al. 2013), which covered the frequency range between 279 and 355 GHz and an SMA survey of the AGB star IK Tau (De Beck et al., priv. comm.). SMA data were obtained for a spatial resolution of 0.9". The line strengths of the SMA data were scaled for a difference in mass-loss rate and distance. Based on the conservative estimate of assuming a smooth distribution, the estimated line strengths for a beam of 0.04" (SG1, this Science Goal) or 0.15" (SG2) were obtained. In SG1, we envision to spatially resolve SiS, SiO, H2O, and CO (see Table 1 in main proposal text) at a resolution of 0.04". The H2O line at 336 GHz is the weakest line for these 4 molecules, with an estimated line strength of ~3.6 mJy/beam. To achieve a SNR of 3 (and higher for the other lines), we request a sensitivity of 1.2 mJy/beam in the requested spectral resolution of 1.129 MHz (0.9 km/s) for SG1 (see Correlator configuration below).
2. Reached RMS for the continuum observations. From the ALMA data, we will get high signal-to-noise measurements of the dust continuum. Assuming a 5 GHz line-free continuum, we obtain a 1 sigma continuum rms of ~18 microJy/beam in SG1.
Dust continuum estimates are based on (i.) measured (far-)infrared spectroscopic and photometric data from IRAS and Herschel of R Dor and (ii.) a comparison between these observed infrared flux levels of R Dor and the ones of the O-rich AGB star IK Tau, a target for which also dust continuum flux densities at 1.3 and 2.6 mm are available. Using the PdBI, the dust continuum flux density of IK Tau was found to be 9+/-1 mJy at 2.6 mm and 28+/-2 mJy at 1.3 mm (Castro Carrizo et al. 2010) (unresolved with beam of 2.6"x1.4"). Using the inferred spectral index of 1.65 yields a total flux density of 56 mJy at 345 GHz. The radio flux densities of Reid & Menten (1997) suggest a stellar contribution of 15-30 mJy and hence a dust continuum within the inner arcsec of 16-50 mJy, concentrated in the inner 500 mas. Scaling for the difference in infrared flux levels (and hence the difference in distance and mass-loss rate) yields a dust continuum estimate for R Dor which is 20% lower than for IK Tau, i.e. 12-40 mJy, within an 800 mas region. For a beam of 0.04" and an r^-2 emissivity law, this results in an average estimate of 70 microJy/beam for detectable continuum in the inner parts of the dust shell.
We will also detect the star, facilitating aligning the data sets.
Estimated integration time: The ALMA OT estimates an on-source intregration time of 3.61 hr, resulting in a total requested time (including calibration) of 10.56 hr.

1. Correlator set-up: We aim to detect and analyze line transitions of H2O, SiO, SiS, CO (in SG1), and in addition AlOH, AlO, TiO, and TiO2 in SG2 (see main proposal text). Each of these transitions has line transitions between 332.4-336.4 GHz and 344.4-348.4 GHz (see Table 1 in main proposal text), which can be covered with one spectral setup.
2. Spectral resolution The requested spectral resolution is 1.129 MHz (0.9 km/s) for SG1 and 1.9 MHz (1.6 km/s) for SG2: To analyze the line profiles properly, we request ~10 spectral resolution elements per line profile. The terminal velocity is 7 km/s for R~Dor, and hence the line width of lines formed in the region where the wind has attained its terminal velocity is ~14 km/s. However, in SG1, we want to trace lines that are formed in the wind acceleration region, i.e. with wind speeds considerably lower than the terminal velocity. Therefore, we request a spectral resolution of 1.129 MHz (0.9 km/s) for SG1 (spectral averaging of 2).
The broad continuum allows a good continuum sensitivity (see previous box) which will enable us to study the dust, to self-calibrate, to subtract the continuum and to obtain accurate spectral baselines.

The focus of this science goal (SG1) is to scan the dust forming region with the aim to accurately determine the silicon budget and wind velocity profile, starting from the stellar surface all the way through the dust condensation region. The angular diameter for the onset of the dust condensation is ~0.15". To spatially resolve this dust condensation region, we request an angular resolution of 0.04".
The largest angular scale is taken equal to the maximum recoverable scale. We will resolve out flux at scales larger than 0.43" (14 stellar radii) for SG1 and 1.5" (50 stellar radii) for SG2, which might be an issue for the CO J=3-2 and H13CN J=4-3 lines. However, retrieving CO emission at a resolution spatially resolving the dust forming region is essential: CO is a very stable molecule not participating in the dust condensation, and will hence allow us to differentiate between different chemical and dynamical processes in the dust forming region.

For SG1, we allow for a spectral smoothing of a factor of 2 to get a spectral resolution of 0.9 km/s. This is needed in order to get enough points per line profile, with an estimated width around 6-14 km/s, with the lines with the lowest line widths being formed in the region before the onset of the dust nucleation. This results in a data rate of 12.21 MB/s, slightly above the policy value of 12 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
As of today, the mechanism triggering the onset of the stellar wind and mass-loss rate in O-rich AGB stars is not yet understood: (1) We still do not know which are the first little dust seeds formed. (2) Launching a wind seems only possible when the grains are already quite large close to the star. (3) The coupling between the formation of some dust species and the large-scale morpho-kinematical structure is still a puzzle.
With the extended configuration of ALMA, we can for the first time spatially resolve the inner wind structure of a very close-by O-rich AGB at a spatial resolution equaling the stellar radius (!) and unravel step-by-step the formation of dust grain via the molecular depletion factors. We will observe the low mass-loss rate O-rich AGB star R Dor, being the star with the second largest apparent size right after the Sun.
By observing key molecular species contributing to the formation of dust grains (SiO, SiS, H2O, AlO, AlOH, TiO, and TiO2), we will be able to answer key questions on the efficiency of gas depletion by condensing onto dust grains, the dynamical structure in the dust forming region and the spatial correlation between the gas and dust species.
